data.title: Auto-indent `decreaseIndentPattern` for empty string causes unexpected problems
data.body:
Not sure if it's been reported already, but I'm pressed for time right now. Sorry if it's a duplicate.

`language-haskell` package used `decreaseIndentPattern: '^\\s*$'` to decrease indentation on empty strings (this was taken directly from Haskell TexMate bundle). Recently, it started causing problems on OSX and simply stopped working on other platforms. See https://github.com/atom-haskell/language-haskell/issues/40 for more information.

I think this is a bug, but I'm not sure, given apparent lack of documentation on the matter.

Thanks.

data.body:

This happens when a file is saved in Atom, but not always: Seems like this happens NOT when there are SOME lines with just whitespace chars, but with many of such lines, this tends to happen always (?). data.title: Tab handling
data.body:
There is an issue with the handling of Tabs in Atom, where tabs get replaced by (multiple) spaces, even with "softTabs: false". Here, tabs get replaced by (value of "tabLength") spaces. At some point, tabs are actually inserted as tabs. Google search found a comment claiming that this would depend on whether there is a "tab as spaces" already existing or not. Could not verify that on MacOS X, Atom 1.0.2.: pressing "tab" almost always adds (value of tabLength) spaces.
Next problem with this is that these spaces are sometimes interpreted as a tab, and at other times not. I.e. if you press "left", sometimes the cursor jumps back just one space (thus interpreting the inserted spaces as actual spaces) and at other times 4 spaces (where 4 is the setting of tabLength for me). Wasn't able to figure out a logic behind that...

Proposal: Change tab handling to that tabs are always treated as tabs and NEVER replaced when "softTabs" is off. Plus, add a short description to the config-pane for that value.

data.title: Help on contributing
data.body:
Hello! This is my first time doing something into a big open source project, and i'm quite lost. But I did solve a problem for future atom versions... I think.

I downloaded Atom and installed some plugins, but it was quite sad when I discovered that Virtualbox and Chrome 41 are screwing everything on Ubuntu. I read https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/6306, and @yuki-takei did some work to make Atom build with newer Electron versions. It looks like Atom is still using atom-shell 0.22 and in that version, Chrome doesn't know how to correctly determine if I'm using a mouse or a tablet.

Ok, I downloaded Yuki's deb package and text selection started working just fine, but a new problem appeared, which I think Yuki already knew and tried to solve by modifying `command-registry.coffee`. The problem is described here https://github.com/atom/notifications/issues/85, where I tried to contribute too. I created this issue to address this problem.

So I forked the atom main repo and applied the same code that Yuki did, but in my case I tried building with electron 0.29.2, which worked fine but the results are the same.

Basically when I try to save a Haskell file with `haskell-language` installed (don't know if there is any relation here, but with .coffee files this doesn't happen) or clicking on the encoding or grammar selector (happens every time in our custom build), it throws a `Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'nodeName' of undefined`. What I did to solve this was to add a new object to the `synteticEvent` object in `command-register.coffee`, in the function `handleCommandEvent`, so the object looks like this now:

```
syntheticEvent = Object.create {},
  eventPhase: value: Event.BUBBLING_PHASE
  currentTarget: get: -> currentTarget
  target: value: currentTarget ####this is the line I added
  preventDefault: value: ->
    originalEvent.preventDefault()
  stopPropagation: value: ->
    originalEvent.stopPropagation()
    propagationStopped = true
  stopImmediatePropagation: value: ->
    originalEvent.stopImmediatePropagation()
    propagationStopped = true
    immediatePropagationStopped = true
  abortKeyBinding: value: ->
    originalEvent.abortKeyBinding?()

#this is some code I took from Yuki's repo
for k, v of originalEvent when k not in syntheticEvent
  syntheticEvent[k] = v
```

There are some other changes in this same file, which can be found at Yuki's repo (#taken from https://github.com/yuki-takei/atom-using-electron-chrome-42/tree/edd8eec11d605ee77459232a010c1ac8a3a1ec42) or at my repo (https://github.com/ricardopieper/atom/blob/master/src/command-registry.coffee).

After adding this `target: value: currentTarget`, the problem stopped happening.

But I don't know the Atom infrastructure, or if this is "correct" Coffeescript/Javascript programming at all. Could someone provide me some feedback? I think this is not necessary for now since it seems like it only happens on newer versions of Electron. I haven't tested the whole application to see if everything is working, but for me at least is working more than before :smile:

I'm happy I solved my problem, but I want to know if I'm going in the right direction.

Thanks!

data.title: Enable subpixel AA for tabs, status-bar etc.
data.body:
### Problem

The GPU layer added to the .gutter .tiles cause the surounding UI to also composite layers, like the tas or the status-bar. This disables subpixel anti-aliasing and text doesn't look that sharp.

Eventhough the `.gutter` has `overflow: hidden`, it seems Chrome still thinks there is a chance of overlapping and thus creates the extra layers.
### Solution

Creating an own stacking context with `z-index` for the `.gutter` seems to fix it.

![z-index](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/8700714/7bbbe614-2b48-11e5-834b-c4f72630c089.gif)

Fixes #7904
